job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Devens, MA
pros: Truthfully the only thing positive that came out of working here were the amazing people I have worked with and amazing friends I have made. Although it is a job, the patients I was able to touch or be apart of their journey of mental health recovery was indescribable.
cons: I have worked for this facility for over a year now on the young adolescence unit. When I first started it was an amazing place to work, not that it was perfect (no healthcare job is) - but I never ever dreaded coming to work. I loved the team I worked with and genuinely felt heard if I brought up any concerns working on the unit. Within the past 5-6 months there have been many changes within management. We had almost all previous nursing supervisors leave along with constant revolving HR representatives since none of them stayed for more than a month. As if working in a psych ward isn't mentally draining as is - management and higher ups made it so much worse and it continues to get worse. HR consistently blames staff for every rising problem. For example, there were lots of safety concerns regarding patient to staffing ratio and MULTIPLE restraints a day by a single patient who was assaulting and sending MULTIPLE staff members to the hospital daily. DMH received a call from numerous staff members telling them about the acuity and how unsafe it was for staff let alone patients. Unbelievably (I wish I could attach this email), HR sent out a hospital-wide email claiming that all problems are at fault of MHCS and "our attitudes" which in turn are effecting the patients. From mental health counselor stand point something I that does not sit right with me is the constant reminder that we are not actual counselors at all, in other words they basically just reminded us that we are basically babysitters nothing more. Nothing more until all the group counselor quit and MHCs were expected to take on the role of someone who makes over 80,000 a year on a $18 salary. We are always the ones expected to go above and beyond but get treated like we are at the absolute bottom of the pyramid.

review_title: If you like feeling defeated, this is the place for you
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Devens, MA
pros: I wish that I had some pros to share, if I absolutely had to find one it would be that EVS staff are some of the hardest workers in the whole hospital.
cons:
The downsides to working at TVBHC, are plentiful! The first is the pay is far from what it should be, secretary's get paid more than counselors. Benefits are terrible, for a hospital, the quality of the insurance is lousy. 

Staff to patient ratio is very unrealistic, the department that reviews and accepts patients consists of non clinical staff who are not qualified to determine whether or not a patient is a suitable admission. They scan referrals and somehow overlook drug seeking patients, violent patients, patients who have been in-patient at TV before and were not appropriate then. This shows the staff that you don't care about them, or their safety. I should have known staff safety wasn't a priority when they decided to get rid of security. They take so many patients who are admitted on Suboxone and Methadone, patients who are withdrawing and demanding meds are not suitable for the units, especially when they are already highly acute. 

I think it had great potential when it opened, but I truly believe that the vision is so far from what they say it is. I worked tirelessly, trying to always make a difference, I was a great employee and was treated terribly. They do not like when you speak up, it doesn't matter what the issue is, it's frowned upon. When real reviews come in and they are negative, they are met with the standard reply from HR that they value their employees and to call them if you want to talk further. They solicit staff to write reviews which are fed through HR and submitted as "verified employee" and this happens when there have been a lot of negative reviews. A good example would be the 20 reviews posted the last week of September and the first week of October on another popular review site. I believe this is an attempt to bury the negatives and prospective employees scan a dozen or so and only see the solicited reviews. When reviews point out issues and are 100% true, the company will flag it and request it be removed. 

It bothers me that in this day and age a company can be so dismissive towards staff concerns. Once you began feeling unsafe and under valued, it's time to move on. If people take the time to look at all the reviews available through a web search you will see a common theme and that is management treats the staff terribly and complaining won't get you anywhere, you will learn fast that you are replaceable and that your feelings, no matter how justified do not matter.

review_title: Understaffed, no security, high turnover for all positions.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Devens, MA
pros: Unit staff genuinely care about each other and the patients
cons:
The mission statement of this hospital is care reimagined,  but the reality of day to day working conditions contradict that. This company has been losing money from its inception despite full units. The management cuts from the bottom, eliminating materials needed to work with patients,  basic maintenance (the units are always dirty, housekeeping has been understaffed and cut from later shifts and nurses and counselors are expected to add cleaning their units in addition to their already scheduled tasks and care of the patients.  We have been told not to "worry about sanitizing surfaces and to use a wet washcloth to wipe down tables." "Not to use gloves when on checks" despite the fact that the doors to patient rooms haven't been cleaned and we are required to touch each and check inside the rooms every 15 minutes  around the clock.  Every day there is a new email with further restrictions on access to necessary materials: gloves are in short supply. Dont use gloves, masks, oxyvir wipes to sanitize surfaces..." 
Security was entirely cut last April.  We have zero security guards. When there are violent incidents and codes called on units, no security is there to assist. The numbers of stagg injured in codes is staggering. The woman in charge of CPI training was punched so hard in the face during a code, she was out on workers compensation for four months with a concussion and complications from that concussion.  They continually admit patients with a history of violence despite the injuries to staff. Debriefings are few and far between. I've been with this company almost since the start and its heartbreaking to see how bad things are. Dont believe them when they say they welcome feedback and wish employees who've posted on this site had come to them. Its not true. We all voice our concerns in staff meetings, and emails. We ask for support and better screenings. We ask for materials to work with our patients all the time. We send work orders for repairs to our units, and write requests for additional and appropriate staffing all the time. You have to be careful. Speaking up and disagreeing puts a target on your back. Those who have, have been pushed out or fired under suspicious circumstances.  We've lost so many key people, so many good people.  The Human resource department should be the department you can go to for assistance,  but here it has become an extension of the CNOs voice. Someone not to be trusted.
